Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of a High Resolution Plasma Source Mass Spectrometer and Sample Introduction System for Multidisciplinary Geosciences Research and Education
Award.AbstractNarration:
The elemental composition of natural waters, sediments, airborne dust, rainwater and marine microbiota contains information that is essential to an understanding the workings of Earth system, and its past and future trajectories, which are of fundamental importance to human society. Moreover, the ability to perform and interpret such chemical analyses is an essential part of the education and training of many scientific professionals within the field of ocean and earth sciences. Among the most commonly used methods for such elemental analyses is plasma source mass spectrometry, whereby a new generation of sample introduction systems coupled to a high-resolution inductively-coupled plasma mass spectrometer (HR-ICP-MS) allows routine elemental determinations in a wide variety of natural materials, over large ranges in elemental concentrations.

This Major Research Instrumentation award will support the acquisition of a new, state-of-the-art HR-ICP-MS and dedicated sample introduction system, which will be housed in Old Dominion University's Department of Ocean, Earth and Atmospheric Sciences (OEAS). This equipment represents an essential replacement and upgrade of the 16-year-old system now in place, and is critically required to meet the current and future research demands of departmental faculty and graduate researchers, as well as provide essential training and education to OEAS postdoctoral researchers, graduate students and undergraduate majors. The new analytical equipment will be maintained and operated by a dedicated research specialist who is highly experienced in HR-ICP-MS analysis, and who will receive additional specific training in the use and maintenance of the new instrument and sample introduction system.

POR.DRECONTENT:
MRI: Acquisition of a High Resolution Plasma Source Mass Spectrometer and Sample Introduction System for Multidisciplinary Geosciences Research and Education

This Major Research Instrumentation award has supported the acquisition of a new high-resolution inductively-coupled plasma mass spectrometer (HR-ICP-MS) and dedicated sample introduction systems, which are housed in Old Dominion University's College of Sciences Major Instrumentation Cluster.  This new, state-of-the-art instrument is used for the chemical analysis of a broad suite of elements in a variety of natural materials, including natural waters, sediments and microbes.  This new analytical equipment represents an essential replacement and upgrade of a failing 16-year-old system, and is critically required to meet the current and future research needs of faculty, graduate and undergraduate researchers, as well as provide essential training and education to postdoctoral researchers, graduate students and undergraduate majors, in Old Dominion University's Department of Ocean, Earth and Atmospheric Sciences (OEAS).  The new equipment is being maintained and operated by a dedicated research specialist, who is highly experienced in HR-ICP-MS analysis and has received additional specific training in the use and maintenance of the new analytical system.

Intellectual Merit. The chemical composition of natural waters, sediments, airborne dust, rainwater and marine microbes contains information that is essential for understanding the workings of our Earth, and its past and future conditions, which are of fundamental importance to human society.  Moreover, the ability to perform and interpret such chemical analyses is an essential part of the education and training of many scientific professionals within the field of ocean and earth sciences.  Among the most commonly used methods for the analysis of individual chemical elements in natural materials is plasma source mass spectrometry, whereby specialized sample introduction systems are coupled to a high-resolution inductively-coupled plasma mass spectrometer (HR-ICP-MS).  These instruments now allow for the routine, simultaneous measurement of numerous chemical elements in a wide variety of natural materials, over concentrations ranging from from parts per trillion to parts per thousand.  As such, these modern instruments are essential tools for current and future research in the disciplines of paleoceanography, chemical oceanography, and marine biogeochemistry that is being conducted by the faculty and students in OEAS.

Broader Impacts. The main broader impacts of the new analytical facility that is supported by this award is the training of future STEM professionals, via essential contributions to postdoctoral, graduate and undergraduate research work, and to the education of undergraduate students in Old Dominion University's Departments of Ocean and Earth Sciences and Chemistry.
